properties.name: West Hyattsville Metro TDDP- West Hyattsville Commons
properties.description: Posted by RufuslWest Hyattsville Metro District Plan (TDDP)This project will update the 1998 West Hyattsville Transit District Development Plan (TDDP) to implement the recommendations of the 2003 West Hyattsville Metro TOD Strategy completed in FY 2003. This planning effort will be conducted in concert with various public stakeholders, including the City of Hyattsville, Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority (WMATA) Maryland Department of Transportation and Planning (MDOT/Planning), the Governor\'s Office of Smart Growth, and county agencies. The objective of the project is to focus county, state and federal resources to stimulate appropriate transit-oriented development (TOD) at the West Hyattsville Metro Station. Atthe northwest quadrant of Ager Road and Hamilton Road, a joint venture of Centex Homes and Best Industries plan to build: 1) 1,170 multi-family units, 2) 193 townhomes, 3) 226,620 SF office, 4) 69,380 SF retail, 5) 23,000SF community center, 6) replacement parking for metro at cost of 7 million, 7) reclaim flood plain at cost of million,

properties.name: Westrum Homes at Brewerytown Square
properties.description: Posted by Rufusl10/24/2006 Best Real Estate Deal Winner: Brewerytown Square As seen in Philadelphia Business Journal When Bruce Pierson takes a walk through is neighborhood, he sees progress: Vacant buildings being torn down or fixed up. Rowhouses being gutted. Dumpsters being filled up and hauled away. All of it, Pierson said, is proof that his faith in the future of North Philadelphia was justified. "My neighbors and I all have the same outlook about the entire area," said Pierson, a government contractor who bought a home at Westrum Development Co.’s ambitious Brewerytown Square development this past spring. "When you walk around the neighborhood, you see change. Even in the old rowhomes, you see renovations going on. It’s a very bright, forward, progressive feeling." It’s hard to imagine things were quite that promising back in 1997. But it was then, when event the most forward-thinking developers weren’t considering the North Philadelphia neighborhood, that Fort Washington-based Westrum began acquiring the land, bit by bit, for what would eventually become Brewerytown Square. It was no safe bet. Westrum named the development in honor of the neighborhood’s historic beer-brewing tradition, which earned it the name Brewerytown in the late 19th century, but the neighborhood in the late 20th century was known more for its many problems: High crime, a depleted residential base and, eventually, a whole lot of abandoned buildings. Still, Westrum saw promise and value in the area, which was located ideally, they believed, between Fairmount Park, Kelly Drive, the Art Museum and Center City. "Just look at the map," said Tom Hewell, a Westrum community manager. "We’re close to everything – close to the major road arteries, close to all the major cultural things and close to the other more wellknown areas of Philadelphia that have seen such a rise in real estate over the past 15 or 20 years. It just seemed like a home run to build on some of these blighted blocks and turn them into affordable homes." So they did just that. In all, Westrum would buy 17 urban acres – no small feat, especially considering not one single resident was displaced – before beginning work on Brewerytown Square itself, a community of 144 townhouses at 31st and Girard Avenue. Brewerytown offers something that other neighborhoods can’t, said Hewell: High-quality homes at an affordable price. Knowing that their new development wouldn’t have the cachet of the city’s more prominent neighborhoods, Westrum smartly decided to put the Brewerytown homes on the market for a price that might attract first-time homebuyers – exactly the kind of people who were increasingly being priced out of Center City and other neighborhoods. "The majority of our buyers are firsttime buyers," Hewell said. "In Philadelphia right now, it’s not easy to buy a condominium for anything less than 00,000, or 00,000 or 00,000, and that goes right up to million. We put ourselves in a niche where we’re an affordable residential community close to everything else, except we’re establishing a whole new part of Philadelphia, which has now become Brewerytown." Brewerytown Square Brewerytown’s combination of location and affordability is exactly what attracted Pierson, who began his home search last winter after deciding to leave his home in Maple Shade, NJ, to move closer to his daughter. He was looking to at the real estate listings one day when he came across an ad for Brewerytown Square which, until then, he had never heard of. He visited the community first to look at a rental unit, and then began wondering if he should buy instead. "I immediately liked [the community]," he said. "But then I thought, ‘Why should I rent if I could buy? I went down to speak with the people n the sales center, and told them if I was going to buy we had to have settlement before May 1, because that’s when my lease ran out." That was in March. By April, Pierson had his home. "They really accommodated me," he said of Westrum. Hewell said Westrum has gone out of its way to make new residents feel at home – and with good reason. The developer needed to sell homebuyers on a community that is, admittedly, on the edge of some rougher areas. Then Westrum had to get them to stay and, ideally, convince others to move in, too. Westrum also knew, Hewell said, that for new residents to feel at home in their new community, they couldn’t be alone there. The last thing Westrum wanted was to get into a situation where one or two buyers would move into an otherwise empty development. To keep that from happening, Westrum "did a lot of buzz marketing," Hewell said, focusing especially on young professionals. The idea was to create a pent-up demand leading up the opening of sales. "It was a blighted area," Hewell said. "A couple of streets down from us it was maybe a little worrisome for some people. But the idea was to move in a real community, really fast." The plan worked. When sales finally opened, the community’s first 12 homes, priced in the mid-00,000s, sold in a day. Deposits quickly followed for homes that had yet to be built. Demand has been strong ever since. "We were the most affordable option, for a first-time house, for a lot of the buyers," Hewell said. "These people were renting in the Fairmount Park or Art Museum area, paying in rent pretty close to what their mortgage would be." The neighborhood’s increasing popularity can be seen mostly plainly, Hewell said, in home prices, which have increased to the mid-00s. As of the latest count, Westrum has contracts of 76 of the 144 homes at the site. Critical mass is being achieved. "You have a sense of community now," Hewell said. "It’s not just one or two people living here. There are people coming and going from work. A year ago, we had 12 people in one building – we only had one building up. Now we have six buildings up. It’s a lot like an instant community." Pierson agrees. He said he knows all of his neighbors by name. These new neighbors have bonded, he said, in the feeling that they’re doing something wonderful both for a neighborhood that needed a boost and for the city in general. "The location and the people are great," he said. "It’s a great community. We all get along. We have this sense of being pioneers, because its’ almost historic living here. It’s a real transition from what it used to be – and I don’t mean the neighborhood. It’s about the vacant buildings that are being torn down, and the sense that we’re making a new community. It’s exciting that there’s such a future in this area."

properties.name: Woodmore Towne Centre
properties.description: Posted by Rufusl Woodmore Towne CentreFrom the Ground Up More Retail Coming to Prince George\'s By Dana Hedgpeth Washington Post Staff Writer Monday, March 21, 2005; Prince George\'s County may be getting some of the trendier retailers that civic leaders and local shoppers long have sought. A team of developers bought 245 acres at the Capital Beltway and Route 202 in Landover and plans to turn it into a complex of homes, offices and moderate- to high-end retailers that sell furniture, clothing and specialty items. Landover Mall, where only a Sears store remains, may soon find itself across the Capital Beltway from new retailers. (Robert A. Reeder -- The Washington Post) Petrie Ventures Inc. of Annapolis, Erwin L. Greenberg Commercial Corp. of Owings Mills, and Hovnanian Land Investment Group (formerly Washington Homes) bought the property from the former Rouse Cos. of Columbia (now part of mall operator General Growth Properties). The developers said they plan to put single-family houses, townhouses and condominiums, up to 1.5 million square feet of office space, and about 700,000 square feet of retail on the property, one of the area\'s last unclaimed parcels. "It\'s an important site because it\'s very close to the Beltway, and it\'s another opportunity for us to attract unique retailers to the county," said Kwasi G. Holman, president of the county\'s economic development corporation. Prince George\'s County officials have been working to attract varied retailers. A few years ago, Landover Mall closed, leaving only a Sears, Roebuck store open there. The mall sits across the Beltway from Petrie\'s project. Just a few miles south of Petrie\'s project in Largo, there is a new, town-center-style shopping center called the Boulevard at the Capital Centre. It has a DSW Shoe Warehouse, Sports Authority, Circuit City and a movie theater. Although Petrie\'s development team said it has not filed plans with zoning officials, it expects to build some first-floor shops with condos above them, according to Walt Petrie, chairman of Petrie Ventures. Not that the new development is likely to bring luxury merchants to Prince George\'s. "There\'s a lot of people who want me to put a Saks Fifth Avenue or a Neiman Marcus in here, but it will be more moderate-priced shopping," Petrie said. A Trader Joe\'s grocery store? "That\'s not out of the question," he said, and there also are likely to be neighborhood services such as a gym and dry cleaner. Construction is expected to start at the end of the year, with completion in mid-2007.
